cluster.title: Mortgage rates fall below 6% for the first time in over three years.

synthesis.narrative:
## State of the Story: Mortgage Rates Fall Below 6%

### Key Development
Mortgage rates fell below 6% for the first time in more than three years, with the 30-year fixed-rate mortgage averaging 5.98% [1][3][5][6]. This represents a decline from 6.01% the previous week [3] and marks the third consecutive weekly decline [3].

### Historical Context and Comparison
This is the lowest mortgage rate since September 8, 2022, when it was 5.89% [3]. One year ago, the rate averaged 6.76% [1][3]. Mortgage rates peaked at 7.79% in October 2023 [5], and when President Trump took office in January, rates were around 7% [5].

### Market Factors and Outlook
Mortgage rates are influenced by Federal Reserve policy decisions, bond market expectations, and generally follow the 10-year Treasury yield [3]. The 10-year Treasury yield was at 4.02% at midday Thursday, down from about 4.07% a week earlier [3].

Industry experts suggest this could boost the spring home-buying season. "Assuming rates stay below 6%, buyers and sellers are going to start getting back into the market," said Lisa Sturtevant, chief economist at Bright MLS [3]. Freddie Mac's chief economist noted that this rate "combined with the improving availability of homes for sale, is meaningful and will drive more potential buyers into the market for spring homebuying season" [5].

### Housing Market Impact
Despite declining rates helping drive a pickup in home sales during the last four months of 2025, the housing market remains in a slump dating back to 2022 [3]. Sales of previously occupied homes remained at 30-year lows last year [3], and recent data shows home sales posted their biggest monthly drop in nearly four years [3].

### Political Context
The rate decline provides a boost for President Trump, who highlighted falling mortgage rates in his State of the Union address [6]. During his 2024 campaign, Trump promised to bring down mortgage rates, stating at an Arizona rally: "We're going to bring it down very fast... We will drive down the rates so you will be able to pay 2 percent again" [5]. The New York Times notes that "the Trump administration floats measures it says will make housing more affordable" [2].

### Ongoing Challenges
While lower rates may help, sources note that "higher home costs and widespread economic uncertainty is also holding back the real estate market" [6]. The evidence remains "patchy on whether lower rates have meaningfully spurred more activity" [2].

citations.title: U.S. Mortgage Rates Fall Below 6% for First Time in Years
citations.quote: The evidence is patchy on whether lower rates have meaningfully spurred more activity, as the Trump administration floats measures it says will make housing more affordable.

citations.title: Average long-term mortgage rate falls below 6% in time for spring home-buying season
citations.quote: The benchmark 30-year fixed mortgage rate fell to 5.98% from 6.01% last week, mortgage buyer Freddie Mac said on Thursday. One year ago, the rate averaged 6.76%. This latest dip, its third decline in a row, brings it closer to its lowest level since 8 September 2022, when it was 5.89%.

citations.quote: Falling rates could 'drive more potential buyers into the market for spring home-buying season,' says Freddie Mac's chief economist.

citations.title: Mortgage Rates Fall Below 6% For First Time Since 2022
citations.quote: Mortgage rates peaked at 7.79 percent in October of 2023. When Trump took office in January, rates were around seven percent. Since May, rates have been steadily declining.

citations.title: Mortgage rate dips below 6% for the first time since 2022
citations.quote: It's also a boost for President Trump, who boasted about mortgage rates coming down in his State of the Union's address Tuesday. Higher home costs and widespread economic uncertainty is also holding back the real estate market.

deepAnalysis.historicalContext: The sub-6% mortgage rate represents a significant milestone after a dramatic rate cycle that began in 2022. Rates rose from historic lows near 3% during the pandemic to peaks of 7.79% in October 2023 as the Federal Reserve aggressively raised rates to combat inflation. This created a 'rate lock-in effect' where homeowners with low rates became reluctant to sell, contributing to housing inventory shortages. The current decline reflects expectations of Fed policy easing and represents the first meaningful relief for potential homebuyers in over three years, though rates remain well above the sub-3% levels that characterized the 2020-2021 period.
implications: Potential revival of spring home buying season after three years of market stagnation
Political capital for Trump administration's housing affordability messaging
Continued challenges from high home prices may limit rate impact effectiveness
Possible gradual improvement in housing inventory as rate differential narrows
Increased pressure on Fed policy decisions as housing market sensitivity to rates remains high
Real estate industry optimism may drive increased marketing and preparation for buyer influx
